item.title: Python and R
item.description: I recently learned Python in SDS348. Python is a programming language similar to R, but has various differences including better software for neural nets, better deployment of scale/pipelines, and quicker speed. These are some examples of python code! list1=[1,2,3,4] list2=['a','b','c','d'] list1[0] ## 1 list2[-1] ## 'd' list2[::2] ## ['a', 'c'] for i in range(5): print(i) ## 0 ## 1 ## 2 ## 3 ## 4 for letter in "abcdefg": print(letter) ## a ## b ## c ## d ## e ## f ## g mylist = [1, 2, 3, 4] for i in mylist: print(i) ## 1 ## 2 ## 3 ## 4 for letter in "abcdefg": print(letter) ## a ## b ## c ## d ## e ## f ## g i= 1 while i < 11: print(2**i) i+=1 ## 2 ## 4 ## 8 ## 16 ## 32 ## 64 ## 128 ## 256 ## 512 ## 1024 def add_one(x): return x+1 add_one(2) ## 3 import numpy as np x=np.

item.title: Project 2: Modeling, Testing, and Predicting
item.description: Introduction From this last year being very focused on health-care, with COVID-19 affecting the world, I thought I would do a project focusing more on health insurance as it is something very important to have. Health-care in America is very costly which is made more affordable with health insurance, so I was interested to see whether the costs of insurance would be affected by different factors. The dataset “Insurance” data set on Medical costs from Kaggle.

item.title: Project 1: Exploratory Data Analysis
item.description: Introduction This following year, I’m going to be teaching elementary school in Houston as a part of the Teach for America 2021 Corps. Teach for America is a program that enlists graduates to teach at low income public schools in America to help bridge the gap of educational inequity and expand opportunities for children. I was interested in investigating whether there was a correlation of state spending on public education on Fall enrollment in a degree-granting institution.
